channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for SC
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for SC

item.title: Report E-2025020188
item.description:
Report E-2025020188

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T03:17:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-24
  • City: MANNING
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAGLE TRANSPORT CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver had a spill of approximately 10 gallons of diesel or less. Driver attempted to clean it up but did not report as required. Investigation determined that he failed to properly lock the fitting down, did not properly cleanup the spill, and did not properly report as required per company policy. CDG was contacted to manage the cleanup and sent a contractor onsite. They cleaned the concrete with absorbents and swept them into drums. Product did not reach drains, grass, or stormwater.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver overfilled tank and resulted in a release of approximately 10 gallons of diesel. No drains were impacted. CDG managed the response cleanup. Vendor used Oil Dri on the impacted area.

item.title: Report E-2025010097
item.description:
Report E-2025010097

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-08
  • City: SPARTANBURG
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 01/08/2025, at 1215 hours, personnel in the CSXT Spartanburg Yard discovered CELX 206, a loaded tank car of Ethylene, refrigerated liquid, leaking from the top of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Celanese, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-01-08-00139. HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found that the internal pressure of the tank car was at 74 psi and intermittingly venting. Marion Environmental Inc was additionally dispatched to the scene to conduct a flaring operation to reduce internal pressure off from the tank car. The vacuum was obtained from CELX 206 with a reading of 1300-1500 microns which is an indication that the tank car was over pressurizing. The excess pressure was flared off to 46 psi. CELX 206 was then moved to Celanese industry in Enoree SC without any further issues. The issue was identified, and corrective actions, were communicated to the shipperâ€™s representative (Sam Adkins, 304-638-3138).
